required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Evaluation of Cavernous Sinus Invasion by Pituitary Adenoma Using Deep Learning Based Denoising MR
clinical_study.official_title: Prospective MRI Evaluation of Cavernous Sinus Invasion by Pituitary Adenoma Using Deep Learning Based Denoising

brief_summary.textblock: Preoperative evaluation of cavernous sinus invasion by pituitary adenoma is critical for performing safe operation and deciding on surgical extent as well as for treatment success. Because of the small size of the pituitary gland and sellar fossa, determining the exact relationship between the pituitary adenoma and cavernous sinus can be challenging. Performing thin slice thickness MRI may be beneficial but is inevitably associated with increased noise level. By applying deep learning based denoising algorithm, diagnosis of cavernous sinus invasion by pituitary adenoma may be improved.

primary_outcome.description: Presence or absence of cavernous sinus invasion determined surgically

secondary_outcome.measure: Size of pituitary adenoma (in mm), laterality of pituitary adenoma (unilateral or bilateral) on the MRI
secondary_outcome.description: Size of the tumor (in mm), laterality of the tumor (unilateral or bilateral) on the MRI

secondary_outcome.measure: Margin of pituitary adenoma (well-delineated, poorly delineated) on the MRI
secondary_outcome.description: Margin of pituitary adenoma (well-delineated, poorly delineated) on the MRI

clinical_study.condition: Cavernous Sinus Invasion by Pituitary Adenoma

arm_group.description: 1 mm slice thickness coronal contrast-enhanced T1 weighted imaging with deep learning based denoising vs. 3 mm slice thickness coronal contrast-enhanced T1 weighted imaging

intervention.intervention_name: MRI with deep learning based denoising
intervention.description: 1-mm coronal contrast-enhanced T1 weighted image with deep learning based denoising

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients undergoing preoperative brain MR for pituitary adenoma
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients who have any type of bioimplant activated by mechanical, electronic, or magnetic means (e.g., cochlear implants, pacemakers, neurostimulators, biostimulates, electronic infusion pumps, etc), because such devices may be displaced or malfunction
- Patients who are pregnant or breast feeding; urine pregnancy test will be performed on women of child bearing potential
- Poor MRI image quality due to artifacts
